debateSection.name: prelude
debateSection.heading: Prelude
debateSection.summary: Chuaigh an Ceann Comhairle i gceannas ar 10.30 a.m.
Paidir.
Prayer.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: Before proceeding with business I wish on my behalf and on behalf of the Members of Dil ireann to offer a cad mle filte, a most sincere welcome, to a delegation from the Finnish Parliament's committee on jobs and equality, led by the chairperson, Ms Tarja Filatov. I hope you will find your visit enjoyable, successful and to our mutual benefit.

debateSection.name: debate
debateSection.heading: Leaders Questions

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: It was bad enough that the household tax was pushed through come hell or high water by 31 March, with the result that only half of households have registered for payment. Now the country is faced with the water metering debacle, with headlines in The Sunday Times suggesting that people will have to pay up to 300 to install a meter. This was followed by a spokesman for the Department of the Environment, Community and Local Government saying that both the cost of buying and installing water meters would be passed on to households and not paid for by the Exchequer. We then had the Taoiseach stating:

There will not be an installation charge for the householder because that cost will be covered as a loan from the National Pensions Reserve Fund to the Department. There will be a cost for the meter itself.

On RTE Radio's "This Week", the Tnaiste articulated a third position, that no decision had yet been made on how water meters are to be paid for. As if these confused statements were not enough, on Monday the Taoiseach repeated that while there would be no charge for the installation of water meters, somebody will have to pay for them.

The Minister for Jobs, Enterprise and Innovation, Deputy Bruton, added the Government was awaiting proposals on metering from the Department of the Environment, Community and Local Government. The Minister for Finance, Deputy Noonan, stated that no formal decision had been taken but that he saw meters as a friend of householders, businesses and so on. All of this took place on the same day the Irish League of Credit Unions painted a stark picture of more than 47% of households having less than 100 in disposable income per month.

speech.from: Deputy Brendan Howlin
speech.p: Whose fault is that?

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: A question, please.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: I suggest the Government already is out of touch.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: A question please.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: It does not have a clear and detailed plan on how water metering is going to work.

speech.from: Deputy Michael McNamara
speech.p: At least we know what we voted for.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: This has been a shambolic and farcical situation. There are no detailed costings, no detail on exemptions and no details on how the Government expects to put water meters into all households by 2014-----

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: A question, please.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: -----which would require an installation rate of 4,000 per day. Moreover, while the actual cost of meter installation has been quoted as being 800 per house, Professor Gray of Trinity College Dublin has stated that meters can cost anything from 90 to 700.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: A question please, Deputy. We are over time.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: Can the Taoiseach bring clarity to this issue this morning? How much will this water metering system cost the average householder? Second, what are the job loss implications in the 34 local authorities? I note when this happened in Northern Ireland, more than 800 jobs were lost in local authorities there-----

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: Thank you Deputy. We are way over time.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: -----which would equate to approximately 1,300 jobs in this jurisdiction.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: Deputy, we are way over time.

speech.from: Deputy Brendan Howlin
speech.p: The Deputy is willing harm on us.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: Third, will the Taoiseach ensure the appearance in the House today of the Minister for the Environment, Community and Local Government, Deputy Hogan-----

speech.from: Deputy Billy Kelleher
speech.p: He cannot find him.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: -----to make a detailed statement to bring clarity to this issue and to answer questions from Members of this House?

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: Deputy, please. We are over time.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: It is the hapless Minister of State, Deputy O'Dowd, who always is sent out. Where is the Minister, Deputy Hogan? The Minister, Deputy Hogan, should come into the House to give a detailed statement and answer a few questions on it for the benefit of the House and the public.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: Before calling on the Taoiseach, I remind Deputies there are two minutes for asking a question and three minutes for a reply. I ask everyone to adhere to those limits.

speech.from: Deputies
speech.p: Hear, hear.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: The Minister, Deputy Hogan, is in Denmark today to attend a meeting of European Union Ministers. The Government made two decisions today. First, it decided that Irish Water would be set up as a subsidiary of Bord Gis ireann in public ownership, with no intention of privatisation of the Irish water system. Second, the Government made a formal decision that there would be no upfront charges on anyone in respect of the provision of water and that charging for water will not begin until 2014. That deals with the three questions Deputy Martin asked. The Government now has two years in which to work out the detail of what is involved in this regard. There will be no job losses in the 34 local authorities but an additional 2,000 jobs will be created for those men and women who are quantity surveyors, engineers, plumbers and people working in the water system. I repeat the Minister, Deputy Hogan, is in Denmark.
I might point out to Deputy Martin that on his first day back in the House, it ill behoves him to take the opportunistic line he is taking.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: I simply asked a question.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: I am not in any way commenting on the speculation one always will have regarding issues that arise in politics in the normal course of events. However, I want Deputy Martin to understand that the actions of the Governments of which he was a member have left the Government with this unprecedented mess. The present Administration has the courage to sort it out and is not so doing by perpetrating a scam on the Irish people to the effect that one can run all the country's services with the tax revenues coming in from property speculators. The Government has chosen to not increase income tax. It has chosen to not impose a tax on work, employment and jobs.

speech.from: Deputy Billy Kelleher
speech.p: Yet.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: It is transferring responsibility in this area to consumers, who will have a choice. Moreover, the Government has built in protections in all things to date for consumers. It intends to change the entire transmission system of the way in which water, which is a precious resource, is dispensed nationwide. Deputy Martin is aware of the impact, economically, personally and socially, of what happened with the cryptosporidium case in Galway. He is familiar with the difficulties that arise when people receive notices that they are obliged to boil water. He is aware of the volumes of high-quality, pristine, safe and clean water that now are demanded in Ireland, where there are high levels of confidence for investment about which I hope to make a further announcement today. We cannot continue in the manner that obtained in the past, whereby 40% of the water from reservoirs never gets to the facilities or to those who are supposed to use it. The Government must deal with this problem and will deal with it in as fair, as equitable and as affordable a way as possible. There will be no charges until 2014. An assessment in respect of the level of investment that will be required in respect of the roll-out of water metering will commence very shortly.

Bord Gis ireann has been a public utility company for many years. It has a brilliant record in the context of dealing with consumers, the payment of bills, pipelines, business, enterprise, governance, etc. It and Bord na Mna submitted substantial proposals in respect of this matter in response to the Government's desire to retain Irish Water as a public utility in public ownership. Earlier this morning I heard Deputy Donnelly referring to tenders and contacts with a view to privatising Irish Water.

speech.from: Deputy Timmy Dooley
speech.p: That is your agenda.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: That is not the case nor is it the intention of this Government.

speech.from: Deputy Michael Healy-Rae
speech.p: Not yet.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: With the greatest respect, I asked the Taoiseach how much this is will cost the average householder and he did not answer my question. In fact, he avoided the question in its entirety.

speech.from: Deputy Michael McNamara
speech.p: Did Deputy Martin put that question to Brian Cowen when the Government of which they were members voted in favour of a certain course of action?

speech.from: Deputy Finian McGrath
speech.p: Deputy McNamara should calm down.

debateSection.summary: (Interruptions).

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: The Taoiseach stated that there is a large amount of documentation available and that comprehensive submissions have been made by Bord Gis ireann. Will the Taoiseach publish such documentation and also the advice the Government received?

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: The Deputy should ask a supplementary question.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: The Taoiseach should publish all of it.

speech.from: Deputy Pat Rabbitte
speech.p: Deputy Martin would not read the information if it was published. He never read such material when he was in government.

debateSection.summary: (Interruptions).

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: The real scam that has been pulled off relates to the election commitments made by the Taoiseach and his colleagues last year. I am aware that the Tnaiste was in difficulty on Sunday as a result of the Labour Party conference.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: A supplementary question, please.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: I took the Tnaiste at his word when he stated that a decision has not been taken. However, I suspect that something else may have been going on. In 2009, the Labour Party had a very clear position on this matter when it indicated that "water is a basic and fundamental need and should not be treated like a market commodity".

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: I would prefer if we had questions rather than statements.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: At that time, Deputy Tuffy stated "Charging for domestic water, in the light of our current taxation system, will only add to inequality, since such charges don't take account of people's ability to pay." She also stated "The Labour Party abolished water charges when Brendan Howlin was Environment Minister in the Rainbow Govt, 1996. We would oppose any attempt to reverse that move."

speech.from: Deputy Jerry Buttimer
speech.p: Has the Ceann Comhairle's clock stopped?

debateSection.summary: (Interruptions).

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: The Taoiseach obviously brought the Tnaiste into line in respect of this matter prior to today's sitting. How does he propose to ensure that people's capacity to pay will be taken into account?

speech.from: A Deputy
speech.p: Deputy Martin needs a drop of holy water.

speech.from: Deputy Finian McGrath
speech.p: Get out your pepper spray.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: Perhaps it might be possible to have some holy silence.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: Deputy Martin quoted the Tnaiste and Deputy Tuffy. He could have used a quote from amon de Valera who promised to drain the Shannon many years ago.

debateSection.summary: (Interruptions).

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: I was referring to statements made prior to the most recent general election.

speech.from: Deputy Finian McGrath
speech.p: What about the comments on Roscommon Hospital?

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: A lot of water has flowed under the bridge since then. Perhaps Deputy Martin might enlighten the Dil at some stage with regard to what he actually said himself on the night during which the Government of which he was a member-----

speech.from: Deputy Finian McGrath
speech.p: What did the Taoiseach say about property tax?

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: -----lumped 70 billion in debt onto the backs of taxpayers on foot of the debacle in the former Anglo Irish Bank.

debateSection.summary: (Interruptions).

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: Answer the question.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: Perhaps the Deputy might comment on the matter to which I refer at some point. The position is that the Government made a decision yesterday in respect of-----

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: How much is it going to cost the average household?

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: -----allocating responsibility for the establishment of Irish Water to Bord Gis ireann. The Government also made a decision that there would be no up-front charge and that charges would not be imposed until 2014. The Government will also make the decision regarding the free allowance consumers will receive in respect of water. However, in accordance with tradition, the regulator will have responsibility for the structure and the detail of what will be involved.

The ESB has been a public utility company for very many years. Neither I nor the Deputy can inform people as to what will be the cost of electricity in five years' time. It is daft to ask what will be the charge for water when the details of the matter have not even been discussed or worked out. The relevant regulator will have responsibility in this area.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: There is no hiding behind the regulator.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: I met the various regulators last summer and informed them that the primary interest of the Government lies is-----

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: No hiding behind the regulator.

speech.from: Deputy Tom Hayes
speech.p: Fianna Fil hid behind every regulator it ever appointed.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: -----in the protection of consumers and the creation of jobs.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: The Taoiseach's time is exhausted.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: All regulators must bear in mind the various sensitivities and consequences involved when they make decisions. On a previous occasion the House had discussions and made recommendations in respect of situations where an increase in the price of oil would lead to a corresponding increase in the cost of electricity.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: The Government is going to abolish all regulators. The Minister for the Environment, Community and Local Government, Deputy Hogan, put forward the proposal in that regard.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: The various regulators must bear their responsibilities in mind.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: I thank the Taoiseach.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: There will be a two-year gap before all of these details will be worked out. There has been speculation across a broad spectrum-----

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: It was not speculation.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: The decisions made were that, first, Irish Water would be set up by Bord Gis ireann and-----

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: The statements came from the Ministers and the Government.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: -----second, there would be no upfront charge for anybody.

speech.from: Deputy Jerry Buttimer
speech.p: The Deputy should listen.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: It is not speculation

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: Third, there would be no charge until 2014.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: It is not speculation.

speech.from: Deputy Jerry Buttimer
speech.p: Listen.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: Fourth, there will be 2,000 jobs created, and fifth, there will be a transformation in the delivery of Irish water, and there will be no increase in income taxes or taxes on employment, which was a decision made by the Government. All consumers understand that this precious commodity is not free and when this system is in place, the Government will decide the free allocation per person, after which a charge will apply-----

speech.from: Deputy Niall Collins
speech.p: I thought it would come from the regulator.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: -----and that charge will be determined by the regulator. One does not go to bed at night and leave on all the electrical appliances in the house because people know electricity must be paid for.

speech.from: Deputy Richard Boyd Barrett
speech.p: The Government will have pensioners afraid to turn on any appliances.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: We cannot have a position where taps could be left running endlessly.

speech.from: Deputy Niall Collins
speech.p: Or turn on the radio.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: There has been much leaking from the Government in the past couple of days and weeks.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: In many cases where meters apply-----

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: The Government could turn off a couple of taps.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: The Deputy can see them in many places around the country.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: The Government is leaking left, right and centre. It is leaking against itself.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: The saving in consumption and cost would be serious.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: Could I have the co-operation of everybody please? We are way over time.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: This will lead to the creation of a whole new level of confidence and competence in the Irish water system, not just for now but for the next 50 years.

speech.from: Deputy Niall Collins
speech.p: What about the jobs?

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: I remind Deputies that we are now five minutes over time on the first question.

speech.from: Deputy Jerry Buttimer
speech.p: Deputy Martin was good at leaking himself.

speech.from: Deputy Mary Lou McDonald
speech.p: I extend sympathies to Deputy Pearse Doherty on the sudden death of his father, who is being laid to rest this morning. Ar dheis D go raibh a anam dlis. They say that lightning does not strike twice but the Minister for the Environment, Community and Local Government, Deputy Hogan, seems to be disproving that maxim. May we have a couple of straight answers from the Taoiseach? He has said there will be no upfront charge so is he therefore stating that people will not be charged for the installation of meters? Will he tell us whether this Government is really considering the prospect of cutting off the water supply to houses in the event of a charge not being paid? This is a strategy that was indicated by one of the Ministers. Does he believe that in this day and age that would be any kind of a civilised option?

The Taoiseach has stated there will be a number of years for the details of this scheme to be worked out and that the regulator must have an eye to the consumer and hardships that might ensue. I ask those on the Government benches to in the first instance have that eye to the citizen because the reaction of the public to yet another charge is one of wondering where they will get the money and wherewithal to meet the cost. Substantial numbers of people have not registered and will not register for the household charge for the very simple reason that they cannot afford it. Equally, hardship will ensue-----

speech.from: Deputy Tom Hayes
speech.p: Can the Deputy afford it?

speech.from: Deputy Mary Lou McDonald
speech.p: -----from this charge.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: Is there a question?

speech.from: Deputy Mary Lou McDonald
speech.p: The Taoiseach has made a virtue of the fact that he will not touch income tax and it is clearly a matter of doctrine that the Government will not tax the very wealthy. It is fairly gung ho about imposing charge after charge on lower and middle income people. What will the charge be for the installation of meters? Will the Taoiseach give a guarantee that whatever way this scheme works, the Government will not countenance, in any circumstances, cutting off water supply to homes?

speech.from: Deputy Tom Hayes
speech.p: Did the Deputy pay her household charge?

speech.from: Deputy Finian McGrath
speech.p: Deputy Hayes should calm down.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: I am not sure if the Deputy checked with her counterparts in Northern Ireland but the party seems to have a very different philosophy in this part of the island. The position is that there will be no upfront charge and when this system is worked out by the regulator, the cost of the system will be subsumed into the standing charge to be determined by the regulator. The people living in the Deputy's constituency will not be given an upfront bill for payment.
Electricity is a public utility-----

speech.from: Deputy Dessie Ellis
speech.p: For how long?

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: -----and a standing charge is determined by the regulator, as it has been for very many years. With regard to the comment about people being cut off, these are all matters for discussion with regard to how the system will work. If a person does not pay an electricity or phone bill, the service is cut off. Water is fundamental for life and if the Government states that everybody will receive a free allowance, that speaks for itself.

speech.from: Deputy Joe Higgins
speech.p: There is no free water; we pay for it through our taxes.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: Clearly the system here is for everybody to understand that we cannot go on the way we have been going on, we cannot continue to have 40% of water leaking through systems, we cannot have 30-----

speech.from: Deputy Joe Higgins
speech.p: Then fix the bloody pipes.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: We will fix the pipes.

speech.from: Deputy Brendan Howlin
speech.p: Joe the plumber.

debateSection.summary: (Interruptions).

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: Deputy Higgins has surrendered his leadership and should stay quiet.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: Joe the plumber lost his place and has moved further to the right.

speech.from: Deputy Jerry Buttimer
speech.p: The banshee of Dunquin speaks.

speech.from: Deputy Joe Higgins
speech.p: Deputy Buttimer cannot even get his geography right.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: For the Deputy's information, he can take it as a given that in the general discussions that take place about this matter, the priority of Government is to see, reflect and understand the difficulties that many people have. However, as I have explained to him on many occasions in the past, troika or no troika, we in this country have to sort out our public finance problems ourselves. Nobody will walk in with a cheque and say it has all been paid for. Everybody is involved in this and the Government understands the burden on those who have real difficulty, which is why we have introduced waivers, exemptions and regulations which lessen that burden.
The question was asked of somebody yesterday whether VAT will be imposed on water. The answer is "No" because, as Deputies know, water is exempt from VAT under European regulations.

speech.from: Deputy Dessie Ellis
speech.p: The Government is paving the way for privatisation.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: On the cost of the installation of water meters, I have seen in today's newspapers reflections of various costs of meters, from 30 to 200 to 300, and the cost of installation in various locations around the country. That is all a matter for discussion and determination by Bord Gis when it sets up Irish Water together with the regulator. As I stated, the Government will determine what will be the free allocation.

speech.from: Deputy Mary Lou McDonald
speech.p: To set the record straight, more than 1 billion has been invested in water improvement in the North where there are no household water charges - we saw to that - and no prospect of the water service being privatised. Those are the facts.

debateSection.summary: (Interruptions).

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: Will the Deputy please ask her supplementary question?

speech.from: Deputy Mary Lou McDonald
speech.p: I find it astonishing that the Taoiseach states it will be a matter for discussion whether water supply would be cut off to houses and homes across the State.

speech.from: Deputy Tom Hayes
speech.p: He did not say that.

speech.from: Deputy Mary Lou McDonald
speech.p: To quote him directly, he stated it will be "a matter for discussion". There cannot be any discussion on that issue.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: A question, please.

speech.from: Deputy Mary Lou McDonald
speech.p: Water, as the Taoiseach conceded, is essential for a decent standard or quality of living. He stated the speculation as regards costs that is doing the rounds in the public arena is just speculation. However, in the absence of any clarity from the Government, there will be such speculation. The Taoiseach has failed this morning to indicate in any substantive way for the citizens of the State what level of charge they will face. It is most astonishing that he will not rule out the prospect of cutting off water supply to homes. That is a disgrace and I ask him, when he gets to his feet again in a moment, to make crystal clear to people who are very worried as they watch this that the water supply to their homes will not be jeopardised.

speech.from: Deputy Brian Hayes
speech.p: The Deputy is making people worried.

debateSection.summary: (Interruptions).

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: Deputies must allow the Taoiseach to reply.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: Let me repeat what I said for Deputy McDonald, as I did for Deputy Martin. What the Government decided yesterday was that Irish Water would be set up as a publicly owned utility.

speech.from: Deputy Mary Lou McDonald
speech.p: I heard all of that.

speech.from: Deputy Tom Hayes
speech.p: She did not listen.

speech.from: Deputy Mary Lou McDonald
speech.p: I ask the Taoiseach to answer my question.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: I understand Deputy McDonald's leader is at the socraid of Michel Doherty and I extend our sympathies to Deputy Pearse Doherty on the loss of his father.

I remind her of the comment made by her leader yesterday that this was about the privatisation of water. It is nothing of the kind. In fact, the legislation will strengthen the position that this is a publicly owned utility. That is why when expressions of interest were sought on who might run and set up Irish Water two existing semi-State bodies responded, not private companies which, in the words of Deputy Donnelly, would have a contract or tender awarded to them for the privatisation of water. This is a universal product. A universal transmission for high quality water is so important for both business and for personal life.
The Deputy should not say in this House that I said people would have their water cut off.

speech.from: Deputy Jonathan OBrien
speech.p: She did not say that.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: There will be no bills of any kind for water for two years.

speech.from: A Deputy
speech.p: The Taoiseach said it was an option.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: We are over time.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: As I said to Deputy Martin, the ESB has been a public utility for many years yet we cannot determine the cost of electricity in three years time or five years time because we do not know what the geopolitical effects of events abroad might be.

speech.from: Deputy Dessie Ellis
speech.p: Privatisation.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: If I said to the Deputy that the Cabinet decided yesterday to go ahead with Metro North, she would ask me the cost of the tickets. The detail of these major schemes has to be worked out.

speech.from: Deputy Mary Lou McDonald
speech.p: I am asking about the guaranteed supply of water to homes. It is a very simple question.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: I want to put people's anxieties at ease here. Bord Gis ireann will set up Irish Water as a publicly owned utility. There will be 2,000 jobs for young men and women to install water meters. There will be much more conservative and careful use of a scarce product.

speech.from: Deputy Mary Lou McDonald
speech.p: Will people have their water cut off?

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: We will respect the importance of consumer protection, which is a point I made last year to all of the regulators. The Deputy need not run off now out of the Chamber and make wild statements.

speech.from: Deputy Joe Higgins
speech.p: Look at the evidence. Water usage per household-----

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: Deputy Higgins, will you please stay quiet?

speech.from: Deputy Joe Higgins
speech.p: There is no evidence-----

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: Welcome back, Joe the Plumber.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: I call on Deputy Ross.

speech.from: Deputy Shane Ross
speech.p: Thank you Ceann Comhairle. On behalf of the Technical Group, I would like to join with Deputy McDonald and the Taoiseach in expressing our sympathy to Deputy Doherty on the death of his father.

Yesterday the Cabinet moved to end the confusion which had existed about these water charges, following a report in The Sunday Times last Sunday. We should greet that with a certain amount of optimism, but having heard it, to be honest I prefer the confusion to the clarification. We now know a few very limited things about what will happen with water charges. We know that the Government, in its wisdom, has decided to create another State monopoly with a free hand to charge consumers a completely unspecified amount of money at its own discretion.

debateSection.summary: (Interruptions).

speech.from: Deputy Shane Ross
speech.p: Well if you tell us how much it is, that would be fine.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: Through the Chair, please.

speech.from: Deputy Shane Ross
speech.p: The second thing is what the Americans call the known unknown. We know there will be a 40 charge and we know that that voted 40 charge-----

speech.from: A Deputy
speech.p: No we do not.

speech.from: Deputy Shane Ross
speech.p: It is a standing charge of 40, more or less. We know that this charge will be used to repay a loan given by the National Pensions Reserve Fund. Why are the people borrowing money from the National Pensions Reserve Fund? We are borrowing our own money when we do that. This contrasts completely with what happened to the National Pensions Reserve Fund when the banks went to it. When the banks went to the NPRF - a great misnomer because no pension will ever be paid from it - they were given money. An equity investment was made and they will never have to repay most of the money, as everybody knows. Why did the Government not direct the NPRF to put this money into the installation costs so that people do not have to borrow it? Why is this fund, which was pillaged by the banks for money which they will not pay back, being loaned to the people, who are going to have to pay back? We could treat the people at least the same as we treat the banks and allow them to take the money, thereby abolishing that 40 charge.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: I thank the Deputy for accepting the principle of what is involved here. What is involved is transforming the way in which water, as a valuable, precious entity, has been dealt with in this country.

Over the next 25 to 50 years it will become even more important and it is critical that the Government now sets in place a system and platform by which water can be delivered to homes and businesses for use in an entirely safe, competent and absolutely professional manner. That is why the Government was anxious that this would be retained as a public entity and as a public utility. Otherwise, if one goes the other route of privatisation and competition for the supply of water among private companies, in our view that would have disastrous consequences. That is why we are very clear about this being a utility retained in public ownership.

The reason for the loan being made in the way it will be made is to provide a commercial return for pensions for people for the future. The Government, as the Deputy will be well aware, does not have any pot of free money to allocate as it so wishes. It is all the people's money one way or the other. We want to deal with the question of serious savings having regard to leaks, investment in proper infrastructure for the carrying and the transmission of water, and the large-scale evidence of water leaks between public boundaries and private houses, of which there are many cases. People do not want that to be an issue with which they cannot deal.

What is involved is a clear Government decision about a way to deal in the future with a resource that has been taken for granted in this country for centuries. We cannot continue the way we have gone before. We must deal with it. The Government decision is absolutely clear in that business and the consumer will take responsibility for their contribution to providing a water system that will continue to inspire confidence in this country from abroad.

As the Deputy will be well aware from his business experience and contacts, it is critical and of fundamental importance for business and major investors that we continue to be able to prove and demonstrate that we have a high quality water system that is safe, clean and in which people can absolute confidence to invest. For personal consumers, it is important that they understand and appreciate, which they do, that this is not a resource that is there to be wasted; it is there to be enjoyed and for use in living, but not to be abused.

speech.from: Deputy Shane Ross
speech.p: I thank the Taoiseach for his reply. I do not disagree with a lot of what he said but he did not answer the question. The question is very simple and maybe I could repeat it. I do not believe that the NPRF - to which the Taoiseach said the money will go back to pay for the pensions in the future - will ever pay a pension. It will be used for infrastructure. It has been used for the banks. It is now a kind of a slush fund for the Government at a time of emergency. It has two forms of funds. It has one for direct - what it called directed - investment and one for discretionary investment. This one is for some reason being used for discretionary investment and the other one, into which the great multiple of the NPRF money has gone, is one that is gone down a black hole into the banks. Why can we not use this 450 million as a direct investment, thereby relieving people of this 40 charge annually over 20 years?

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: As the Deputy will be aware, that decision was made by a previous Government but what we have done here is to supplement the moneys from the NPRF through the PCAR system where we have borrowed to put a foundation in place for banks. The roll-out of this system under Irish Water will provide a unified, unitary, single transmission system of high quality where the exceptional losses through wastage, leakage, broken pipes and different systems operating throughout the local authorities and town councils will be brought under a single high standard and high quality system. That will be good for the consumer, for business and for the country. We recognise the scale of the mess that was left before that was never attended to where, as I said to Deputy Martin earlier, a major scam was perpetrated on the Irish people - that it could be assumed free services could be delivered on the backs of taxes coming from property speculation. When that collapsed, the system collapsed along with it. We must deal with that and will do so in as fair, as equitable and as affordable a way as we can.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: It was Fine Gael that abolished water charges in 1996.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: The Order of Business is No. 11, motion re ministerial rota for parliamentary questions; No. 12, motion re Further Revised Estimates, Votes 2 and 3; No. 4, Thirtieth Amendment of the Constitution (Treaty on Stability, Coordination and Governance in the Economic and Monetary Union) Bill 2012 - Order for Second Stage and Second Stage; and No. 5 Social Welfare and Pensions Bill 2012 - Order for Second Stage and Second Stage to be taken at 9 p.m. It is proposed, notwithstanding anything in Standing Orders, that the Dil shall sit later than 9 p.m. tonight and shall adjourn not later than 11 p.m., Nos. 11 and 12 will be decided without debate and any division demanded on No. 12 shall be taken forthwith. Private Members' Business, which shall be No. 33, Medical Treatment (Termination of Pregnancy in case of Risk to Life of Pregnant Woman) Bill - Second Stage, shall also be taken immediately after the Order of Business tomorrow and shall, if not previously concluded, be brought to a conclusion after 90 minutes on that day.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: There are three proposals to put to the House. Is the proposal that the Dil shall sit later than 9 p.m. tonight agreed to? Agreed. Is the proposal for dealing with Nos. 11 and 12, motions re ministerial rota for parliamentary questions and Further Revised Estimates, Votes 2 and 3, without debate agreed to? Agreed. Is the proposal for dealing with Private Members' business agreed to?

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: In terms of the order, I want to oppose the general order. The Ceann Comhairle is taking items one by one but I want to oppose the order.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: The Deputy must oppose something.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: I will oppose this one then, I am standing to oppose it.

speech.from: Deputy Michael McNamara
speech.p: Oppose everything.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: I am sorry if it has delayed the House.

speech.from: Deputy Michael McNamara
speech.p: Constructive opposition.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: Very constructive.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: Is the Deputy not agreeing to the arrangements for Private Members' business?

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: The bottom line is this: I want to put it to the Taoiseach that we have had commentary left, right and centre about a substantial issue to do with charging for water. Irrespective of one's perspective on it, it goes to the heart of the relevance of this House to debate what is taking place in the country. We have had this on successive days over the weekend. The least this House should do is to allocate time for the Minister of State, Deputy O'Dowd, to make a detailed statement outlining the work that has been undertaken to date on the preparation for the introduction of water metering and all of the detailed proposals that have been submitted by the utility companies for the selection process. It was the worst kept secret that Bord Gis would get this because executives were saying this a number of weeks ago - that is interesting if the decision was only taken yesterday. People seemed to know Bord Gis would get this some time ago so there is a need for the Minister of State to come in, to make a detailed statement and to take questions from Members.
The Taoiseach mentioned the VAT issue this morning. His own Minister of State could not answer the question on that this morning when he was asked it on "Morning Ireland".

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: We cannot have a full discussion on it now.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: There is a need for clarity on the Government side of the House, not from anyone else. We did not start this on Sunday.

speech.from: Deputy Michael McNamara
speech.p: Fianna Fil started it in December 2010.

speech.from: Deputy Brian Hayes
speech.p: Fianna Fil started it.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: The Tnaiste was coming out of his conference and someone sent this Exocet across him; he was a bit startled in the beginning and said he did not think any decision had been taken.

speech.from: Deputy Emmet Stagg
speech.p: Fianna Fil caused the mess.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: There is a need for this House to debate it. I just want the House to discuss it, to have clarity and a detailed presentation. That is all I want. It is being discussed everywhere else.

speech.from: Deputy Michael McNamara
speech.p: Fianna Fil did not discuss things in December 2010. Why did Deputy Martin not discuss it with Brian Cowen? Where was he then?

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: Is this House relevant anymore to anything that goes on?

speech.from: Deputy Pat Rabbitte
speech.p: Deputy Martin and Fianna Fil did not discuss it with this House before signing it off with the troika.

speech.from: Deputy Timmy Dooley
speech.p: I thought the Labour Party was going to renegotiate that.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: As Deputy Martin is aware from his years as Minister for Foreign Affairs, we are preparing for the Presidency of the European Union for the first half of 2013. The Minister for the Environment, Community and Local Government is at a Council of Ministers meeting in Denmark dealing with environmental matters. When the Minister returns there will be no difficulty at all in making as much time as the Deputy wishes available. However, it cannot happen today. Today we are dealing with the European stability treaty. The Deputy was giving out yesterday that there is not enough time to deal with this. It is on the agenda today and is an absolute priority, so we will devote as much time to it as is necessary.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: The Taoiseach could provide 45 minutes extra and we will stay for the extra hour.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: The Deputy can arrange for his party Whip to raise the question of a debate on water for as long as he wishes at this evening's meeting of the Whips-----

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: I am not talking about a Whips' meeting; I am talking about in this House.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: We have no difficulty with talking about this and with dealing with all the issues the Deputy wishes to raise.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: Bring the Minister to the House to make a detailed statement, rather than leaking left, right and centre against each other.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: Deputy Martin should remember there will be two years of discussion on this, between the entity being set up, the regulator, the Government, the House and the people-----

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: So the Minister should come to the House to talk about it.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: -----before any bill is given to anybody. The Deputy will have his opportunity to talk about it-----

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: The Taoiseach is dodging.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: -----and ask as many questions as he wishes. He can raise it at the Whips' meeting tonight.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: It is being discussed everywhere except in this House. That is not a good enough answer. It is the old story.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: Sorry, Deputy, I am trying to bring a little order to the proceedings. We have been away for a fortnight but Members should settle down.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: A Cheann Comhairle, it goes to the heart of the relevance of this House.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: Is the proposal for dealing with Private Members' business agreed to?

debateSection.name: division
debateSection.summary: Question put:
The Dil divided: T, 94; Nl, 28.
Tellers: T, Deputies Emmet Stagg and Paul Kehoe; Nl, Deputies Aengus Snodaigh and Niall Collins.
Question declared carried.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: It has been stated by the Taoiseach that the Government is anxious to raise up to 500 million through a property tax and that it will bring proposals before the House shortly in that regard. Could he indicate when legislation will be introduced?

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: Could we have order please? I am sorry, but could those who are leaving the Chamber do so quietly? We have business to transact in the Chamber.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: Thank you, a Cheann Comhairle. The Government has stated that it wishes to raise 500 million through a property tax. Could the Taoiseach indicate to the House when he intends to bring legislation forward to prepare for the introduction of a property tax?

Given that we now have a date for the European fiscal treaty referendum, could the Taoiseach indicate when it is his intention to bring forward legislation to provide for a constitutional amendment to abolish the Seanad?

speech.from: Deputy Mary Lou McDonald
speech.p: I understand that a committee headed by Dr. Don Thornhill is due to report to the Minister for the Environment, Community and Local Government, Deputy Hogan, shortly on the introduction of a property tax. As the Taoiseach is aware, public speculation is that the proposed tax could amount to 1,000 for home owners.

speech.from: Deputy Emmet Stagg
speech.p: It is nearly as bad as in Northern Ireland.

speech.from: Deputy Mary Lou McDonald
speech.p: Could the Taoiseach confirm when the group will report to Government, whether the report will be published and debated in the Dil and what his plans are to introduce proposed legislation for the property tax?

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: I thank both Deputies for their questions. I saw the report from the ESRI referred to this morning. The Government has its own specialist group which is operating under the chairmanship of Mr. Thornhill, as Deputy McDonald indicated. I do not know when his report will come to Government, but when that happens there will be a full discussion on all such matters. I cannot answer Deputy Martin's question on when legislation will be introduced.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: My understanding-----

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: We have not even got the report back from Mr. Thornhill yet. I have seen the speculation about the ESRI report. That is just speculation. In reply to the question on when we will get the report; I do not know. In reply to Deputy Martin's question on when the legislation will be introduced; I cannot tell him that because we do not have the basis for a discussion on the issue.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: But the Government said it had to be in place by 2013.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: Yes.

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: This is 2012.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: Deputy Martin asked me when I will introduce the legislation. I cannot answer the question for him. I will wait and see what the report states. We have a process of decisions to make following the production of the report. I do not have a date either for the legislation in respect of the abolition of the Seanad. I will speak to Deputy Martin's party and other parties about the proposition in that regard. It is clear that referenda and the holding of them is a matter for public consultation and political decision in the House. I want to do this in the right way.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: Because of the vote we have only seven minutes remaining on the Order of Business and we have seven Deputies offering. I urge them to please be brief.

speech.from: Deputy Joe Higgins
speech.p: Notwithstanding what the Taoiseach said this morning, the Minister for the Environment, Community and Local Government, Deputy Hogan, said yesterday that he was in favour-----

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: I am sorry, Deputy Higgins, but this is not in order. Please. We are not having such a debate.

speech.from: Deputy Joe Higgins
speech.p: -----of having water cut off to people's homes.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: No.

speech.from: Deputy Joe Higgins
speech.p: Yes, he did.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: I do not care what he said. This is not in order on the Order of Business.

speech.from: Deputy Joe Higgins
speech.p: No, but the legislative issue that arises, a Cheann Comhairle-----

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: The Taoiseach has just answered the question.

speech.from: Deputy Joe Higgins
speech.p: -----relates to the Local Government (Financial Provisions) Act 1997. Section 12 removed the power of local authorities to implement water charges for homes and therefore removed the monstrous power to cut off people's water. Could I ask the Taoiseach in that regard what legislative measures - and when - he is bringing forward?

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: I am sorry, but is legislation promised to cut off people's water?

speech.from: Deputy Michel Martin
speech.p: Yes.

speech.from: Deputy Joe Higgins
speech.p: Well-----

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: No legislation is promised so we cannot deal with the matter.

speech.from: Deputy Joe Higgins
speech.p: The Minister for the Environment, Community and Local Government, Deputy Hogan, in response to a journalist clearly indicated yesterday that this was his wish. That needs a legislative response.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: I am not into wishes here. I am into practicalities. Will the Taoiseach clear this matter up?

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: Deputy Higgins wants to go on his sensational rant again. All public utilities, such as Bord Gis ireann and Bord Solthair an Leictreachais, or, as it is now called, Electric Ireland, have protocols in place for persons who have a difficulty. There is a two-year process here for the discussion on the detail and the legislation in respect of Irish Water. I already made the point that the Government made the decision to award the responsibility to set this up to Bord Gis ireann. There will be 2,000 jobs created in the installation of the water meters. The decision of Government is not to increase income tax or to impose further taxes on jobs, and there will be no upfront charge for anybody. No more than any other public utility - this is being retained in public ownership - protocols and details of that matter are for the regulator and Irish Water to deal with over the course of the next two years.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: I thank the Taoiseach.

speech.from: Deputy Richard Boyd Barrett
speech.p: The Taoiseach has stated that there is no question of the privatisation of water. Given that commitment, what legislation will the Government bring forward to insulate the State from the requirements of EU law which necessitate that any revenue-producing monopoly must be subject to EU rules of competition and, therefore, deregulation and privatisation?

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: That is a matter of detail for the legislation.

speech.from: Deputy Richard Boyd Barrett
speech.p: Sorry, this is about legislation.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: Not about promised legislation.

speech.from: Deputy Richard Boyd Barrett
speech.p: It is. The Taoiseach has stated there is no question of privatisation. I am pointing out to him-----

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: We are not into privatisation at this point.

speech.from: Deputy Richard Boyd Barrett
speech.p: -----that EU law requires that once a revenue-producing monopoly-----

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: We cannot have a debate on promised legislation.

speech.from: Deputy Richard Boyd Barrett
speech.p: -----is in place, it must be subject to EU rules on competition.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: Will you be fair to your colleagues?

speech.from: Deputy Richard Boyd Barrett
speech.p: What legislation is the Government bringing forward-----

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: The Deputy should put down a parliamentary question and we will get an answer.

speech.from: Deputy Richard Boyd Barrett
speech.p: -----to copperfasten the Taoiseach's commitment that there will be no privatisation of water given EU law?

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: We are not dealing with that.

speech.from: Deputy Richard Boyd Barrett
speech.p: That is to do with legislation.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: It is nothing to do with legislation.

speech.from: Deputy Richard Boyd Barrett
speech.p: It is.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: It is to do with the content of legislation.

speech.from: Deputy Richard Boyd Barrett
speech.p: It is not.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: We are dealing with when legislation will be taken, that is it-----

speech.from: Deputy Richard Boyd Barrett
speech.p: When will the legislation-----

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: -----not about the detail.

speech.from: Deputy Richard Boyd Barrett
speech.p: When will the-----

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: The Taoiseach has already told the House: two years time.

speech.from: Deputy Richard Boyd Barrett
speech.p: With respect-----

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: I call Deputy Michael McGrath.

speech.from: Deputy Richard Boyd Barrett
speech.p: With respect-----

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: Deputy Boyd Barrett should be cognisant of the fact that there are other Deputies wishing to contribute and there are two minutes and 50 seconds left.

speech.from: Deputy Richard Boyd Barrett
speech.p: I am simply asking what legislation will be brought forward.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: Deputy Boyd Barrett will not bully us here. I ask him to resume his seat.

speech.from: Deputy Richard Boyd Barrett
speech.p: I am not trying to bully anybody.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: I call Deputy Michael McGrath.

speech.from: Deputy Michael McGrath
speech.p: Is it the Government's intention to delay the taking of the Bill which will enable the ratification of the ESM treaty until after the referendum on 31 May? Is it the Government's intention to propose ratification of the ESM treaty irrespective of the result of the referendum on 31 May?

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: The Bill dealing with the treaty to establish the European Stability Mechanism is No. 15 on the A list. This is a short Bill to enable Ireland to ratify the treaty.

speech.from: Deputy Michael McGrath
speech.p: Will it be before the referendum or after it?

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: It is on the A list. I expect it will be dealt with fairly quickly.

speech.from: Deputy Aodhn Rordin
speech.p: Both the Minister for Agriculture, Food and the Marine and the Minister for Justice and Equality have stated that they are working on legislation to introduce a levy on online betting. When might that come before the House?

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: That is No. 11. That is a matter I would like to see dealt with quickly. I expect that it should be dealt with before we rise for the summer. It is a matter that has been raised with me in many places throughout the country.

speech.from: Deputy Michael Healy-Rae
speech.p: The Government has finally published draft legislation that will let the State guarantee up to 75% of loans advanced to small businesses. Could the Taoiseach explain how it proposes to stop the banks using the plan to offload riskier customers onto the taxpayer?

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: We cannot discuss the content. It is only the taking of the legislation we are dealing with now. This is content. If the Deputy tables a parliamentary question, we will make certain he gets an answer.

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: That is the Credit Guarantee Bill published on 10 April and it is on its way through the system.

speech.from: Deputy Charlie McConalogue
speech.p: When can we expect the independent review into child deaths in the care of the State to be published, and why the delay? Can the Taoiseach give an update on when we can expect publication of the fifth report of the special rapporteur into child protection?

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: The Minister is anxious to publish the report but there are a number of matters relevant to it that must be considered by the Attorney General. On the basis of the legal advice coming back to the Minister, she is anxious to publish it as soon as possible. I ask the Deputy not to seek an exact date from me now, but he can take it that once the Attorney General has advised the Minister in respect of elements of the report, she will deal with it.

speech.from: Deputy Charlie McConalogue
speech.p: When can we expect the fifth report of the special rapporteur into child protection?

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: The Minister tells me that she has received the report and that she will publish it shortly.

speech.from: Deputy Timmy Dooley
speech.p: The Taoiseach will be aware that petrol and diesel prices have reached an all-time high. It is having a significant impact on the capacity of the real economy to operate. It is affecting tourism and small businesses. Does the Government have any proposals to bring to this House on changes to both VAT and duties-----

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: Is there legislation promised here?

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: No.

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: There is no legislation promised.

speech.from: Deputy Timmy Dooley
speech.p: -----to moderate the effect of every increase in the base price of oil-----

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: Deputy Dooley is out of order. I call Deputy Niall Collins.

speech.from: Deputy Timmy Dooley
speech.p: -----resulting in a significantly increased take by the State?

speech.from: An Ceann Comhairle
speech.p: I am told there is no promised legislation.

speech.from: Deputy Niall Collins
speech.p: When is it proposed to take the mental capacity Bill?

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: This session, I understand.

speech.from: Deputy Sen Fearghal
speech.p: Was it possible to advance in any way over the Easter period the issue of a constitutional convention and the legislation that may be necessary in that regard? Can the Taoiseach comment?

speech.from: The Taoiseach
speech.p: Yes. I expect to bring a memorandum on this to Government shortly and have informed the members of the parties opposite of where we are headed with it.

speech.from: Minister of State at the Department of the Taoiseach (Deputy Paul Kehoe)
speech.p: I move:

That, notwithstanding anything in the Order of the Dil of 9 March 2011 setting out the rota in which questions to members of the Government are to be asked, questions for oral answer, following those next set down to the Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform, shall be set down to Ministers in the following temporary sequence:
Minister for Social Protection
Minister for Jobs, Enterprise and Innovation
whereupon the sequence established by the Order of 9 March 2011 shall continue with questions to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and the Gaeltacht.

speech.p: I move:

That, notwithstanding Standing Order 159(1) or (2) or the Order of the Dil of 23 February 2012, the following further Revised Estimates for Public Services for the year ending 31 December 2012 be presented to the Dil on 18 April 2012, being a date later than that prescribed for the presentation of Estimates, and that the further Revised Estimates be referred to the Select Sub-committee on the Department of the Taoiseach, pursuant to Standing Orders 82A(3)(c) and (6)(a) and 159(3) of the Standing Orders relative to Public Business:-
Vote 2 (Department of the Taoiseach)
